qas.question: During what time period was the Archean era?
During what period did the earths crust cooling allow the creation of plates?
It is believed that a very warm earth would lead to more recycling of what?
What might have a very hot earth stopped from occurring?
What do some believe accounts for the small amount of Archean rocks?
During what period did tectonic activity become like it is today?

plausible_answers.text: rocks and continental plates began to form

qas.question: What happened as the Earth's crust cooled following the Archean period?
What do scientist think was made more vigerous by the Earth's cooling?
What was recycled more as the earth cooled?

context: The Earth of the <b5_0>early <a1_0>Archean<b5_0/><a1_0/> (<a0_0>4,000 to 2,500 million years ago<a0_0/>) may have had a different tectonic style. During this time, the Earth's crust cooled enough that <b6_0>rocks and continental plates began to form<b6_0/>. Some scientists think because the Earth was hotter, that plate <b7_0>tectonic activity<b7_0/> was more vigorous than it is today, resulting in a much greater rate of recycling of <a2_0><b8_0>crustal material<b8_0/><a2_0/>. This may have prevented <a3_0>cratonisation and continent formation<a3_0/> until the mantle cooled and convection slowed down. Others argue that the subcontinental lithospheric mantle is too buoyant to subduct and that the lack of Archean rocks is a function of <a4_0>erosion and subsequent tectonic events<a4_0/>.
